_link.title: I can identify the organelles present in a cell from a diagram

toLevel2.question: Which organelle has a double membrane with inner folds called cristae?

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria have a double membrane with inner folds called cristae that increase surface area for cellular respiration.

options.text: Chloroplast
options.explanation: Chloroplasts have a double membrane but contain stacked thylakoids called grana, not cristae.

options.text: Rough ER
options.explanation: Rough ER is a single membrane studded with ribosomes, not a double membrane with cristae.

options.text: Cell nucleus
options.explanation: The nucleus has a double membrane with pores but does not contain cristae.

toLevel2.question: What visual feature distinguishes rough ER from smooth ER in a cell diagram?

options.text: Ribosomes on the surface
options.explanation: Rough ER is studded with ribosomes on its outer surface, giving it a 'rough' appearance in diagrams.

options.text: A double outer membrane
options.explanation: Both rough and smooth ER are single-membrane systems; a double membrane is not the distinguishing feature.

options.text: Internal stacks of grana
options.explanation: Grana are found inside chloroplasts, not on the endoplasmic reticulum.

options.text: Pores across the surface
options.explanation: Pores are a feature of the nuclear envelope, not the endoplasmic reticulum.

toLevel2.question: Which organelle is identified by a double membrane and internal stacks of thylakoids called grana?

options.text: Chloroplast
options.explanation: Chloroplasts are recognised by their double membrane and internal stacks of disc-shaped thylakoids called grana.

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria have a double membrane with cristae, not thylakoids or grana.

options.text: Golgi apparatus
options.explanation: The Golgi apparatus consists of flattened membrane sacs but does not have grana or thylakoids.

options.text: Lysosome
options.explanation: Lysosomes are single-membrane vesicles containing digestive enzymes, not thylakoid stacks.

toLevel2.question: In a cell diagram, the nucleus can be identified by which structural feature?

options.text: A double membrane with pores
options.explanation: The nucleus is surrounded by a double membrane (nuclear envelope) that contains nuclear pores for transport.

options.text: Inner folds called cristae
options.explanation: Cristae are the inner folds of mitochondria, not the nucleus.

options.text: Ribosomes on its surface
options.explanation: Ribosomes are found on rough ER, not on the nuclear membrane itself in standard diagrams.

options.text: Stacks of flattened discs
options.explanation: Stacks of flattened discs describe the Golgi apparatus, not the nucleus.

toLevel2.question: Which organelle appears as a smooth, folded membrane system without ribosomes attached?

options.text: Smooth ER
options.explanation: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum is a folded membrane network that lacks ribosomes on its surface.

options.text: Rough ER
options.explanation: Rough ER has ribosomes attached to its outer surface, giving it a dotted appearance.

options.text: Chloroplast
options.explanation: Chloroplasts are discrete organelles with a double membrane and internal grana, not a folded network.

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria are discrete organelles with cristae inside, not a smooth membrane network.

toLevel2.question: Mitochondria can be identified in a diagram by their double membrane and inner folds called cristae.
toLevel2.explanation: Mitochondria have a distinctive double membrane, and the inner membrane folds inward to form cristae.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: Rough endoplasmic reticulum and smooth endoplasmic reticulum look identical in a cell diagram.
toLevel2.explanation: Rough ER has ribosomes on its surface, giving it a dotted appearance, while smooth ER lacks ribosomes and appears as a smooth membrane network.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: In a cell diagram, chloroplasts are recognised by their {{blank:1}} membrane and internal stacks called {{blank:2}}.
The {{blank:1}} is surrounded by a double membrane that has {{blank:2}} for transporting materials.
Rough ER can be distinguished from smooth ER because it has {{blank:1}} attached to its {{blank:2}} surface.

toLevel3.question: Why do mitochondria have cristae extending into their interior?

options.text: To increase surface area for respiration reactions
options.explanation: The folded cristae increase the surface area of the inner membrane where the enzymes for cellular respiration are located.

options.text: To store genetic material inside the matrix
options.explanation: While mitochondria contain their own DNA, cristae serve to increase membrane surface area, not to store genetic material.

options.text: To allow ribosomes to attach to the folds
options.explanation: Ribosomes attach to the rough ER, not to mitochondrial cristae.

options.text: To separate the organelle into two equal halves
options.explanation: Cristae fold inward from the inner membrane but do not divide the organelle into equal halves.

toLevel3.question: How does the structure of chloroplasts support their function in photosynthesis?

options.text: Thylakoid stacks provide membrane for light reactions
options.explanation: The stacked thylakoids (grana) provide a large surface area of membrane where the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis take place.

options.text: Cristae increase the area for glucose breakdown
options.explanation: Cristae are found in mitochondria and are associated with cellular respiration, not photosynthesis.

options.text: Nuclear pores allow chlorophyll to exit the cell
options.explanation: Nuclear pores are part of the nuclear envelope and are unrelated to chloroplast function.

options.text: Attached ribosomes manufacture chlorophyll directly
options.explanation: While chloroplasts contain ribosomes, the stacked thylakoid membranes are the key structural feature supporting photosynthesis.

toLevel3.question: What is the purpose of the pores in the nuclear envelope?

options.text: To regulate the movement of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm
options.explanation: Nuclear pores allow selective transport of molecules such as mRNA and proteins between the nucleus and the cytoplasm.

options.text: To increase the surface area for cellular respiration enzymes
options.explanation: Increasing surface area for respiration is the function of cristae in mitochondria, not nuclear pores.

options.text: To anchor ribosomes for protein synthesis on the envelope
options.explanation: Ribosomes attach to the rough ER, not to the nuclear pores themselves.

options.text: To provide channels for water to enter by osmosis directly
options.explanation: Nuclear pores are selective transport channels for macromolecules, not passive water channels.

toLevel3.question: A student observes a membrane-bound organelle without ribosomes on its surface. Which organelle is this most likely to be?

options.text: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
options.explanation: Smooth ER is a membrane system that lacks ribosomes on its surface, unlike rough ER.

options.text: Rough endoplasmic reticulum
options.explanation: Rough ER is characterised by having ribosomes attached to its outer surface.

options.text: Free ribosome cluster
options.explanation: Free ribosomes are not membrane-bound organelles; they are found floating in the cytoplasm.

options.text: Nuclear outer membrane
options.explanation: The nuclear envelope is a double membrane structure with pores, distinct from the smooth ER network.

toLevel3.question: Why is a double membrane significant for organelle identification in diagrams?

options.text: It narrows the possibilities to the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts
options.explanation: Only the nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts have double membranes, so this feature helps distinguish them from single-membrane organelles.

options.text: It indicates the organelle is always involved in protein synthesis
options.explanation: Double-membrane organelles are not all involved in protein synthesis; mitochondria perform respiration and chloroplasts perform photosynthesis.

options.text: It means the organelle is found only in prokaryotic cells
options.explanation: Double-membrane organelles are found in eukaryotic cells, not prokaryotic cells.

options.text: It shows the organelle cannot be seen under a light microscope
options.explanation: The nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts can often be observed under a light microscope despite having double membranes.

toLevel3.question: How can you distinguish between a mitochondrion and a chloroplast in a cell diagram if both have double membranes?

options.text: Mitochondria have cristae while chloroplasts have grana
options.explanation: The inner structures differ: mitochondria have folded cristae, while chloroplasts have stacked thylakoids called grana.

options.text: Mitochondria are larger than chloroplasts in all cells
options.explanation: Size alone is not a reliable distinguishing feature; their internal structures are the key difference.

options.text: Chloroplasts have nuclear pores but mitochondria do not
options.explanation: Nuclear pores are found on the nuclear envelope, not on chloroplasts or mitochondria.

options.text: Mitochondria have ribosomes on their surface and chloroplasts do not
options.explanation: Neither organelle has ribosomes on its outer surface; ribosomes on a surface are a feature of rough ER.

toLevel3.question: The stacked thylakoids inside a chloroplast are called grana and they are where the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis occur.
toLevel3.explanation: Grana are stacks of thylakoid discs, and the thylakoid membranes are where the light-dependent reactions take place.

options.text: True
False

toLevel3.question: Mitochondria have cristae to increase {{blank:1}} for the reactions of cellular {{blank:2}}.
Only three organelles have a {{blank:1}} membrane: the nucleus, the {{blank:2}} and the chloroplast.
Nuclear {{blank:1}} in the nuclear envelope allow selective {{blank:2}} of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm.

toLevel4.question: A diagram shows a cell with many mitochondria but no chloroplasts. Which conclusion is best supported?

options.text: The cell is an animal cell with high energy demands
options.explanation: Animal cells lack chloroplasts, and a high number of mitochondria indicates substantial energy requirements for cellular respiration.

options.text: The cell is a plant cell in a dark environment
options.explanation: Plant cells still contain chloroplasts even in the dark; they do not lose their chloroplasts based on light availability.

options.text: The cell is prokaryotic with specialised organelles
options.explanation: Prokaryotic cells do not contain mitochondria; membrane-bound organelles are a eukaryotic feature.

options.text: The cell has recently undergone cell division
options.explanation: Cell division does not cause a cell to lose chloroplasts or gain extra mitochondria as a distinguishing outcome.

toLevel4.question: A student labels a structure with a single membrane and no ribosomes as rough ER. What error have they made?

options.text: Rough ER must have ribosomes on its surface
options.explanation: Rough ER is defined by the presence of ribosomes on its outer membrane surface; without ribosomes, the structure is smooth ER.

options.text: Rough ER always has a double membrane structure
options.explanation: Both rough and smooth ER are single-membrane systems; the distinguishing feature is the presence or absence of ribosomes.

options.text: Rough ER is only found in prokaryotic cells
options.explanation: Rough ER is a eukaryotic organelle; prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles.

options.text: Rough ER should contain internal cristae folds
options.explanation: Cristae are internal folds found in mitochondria, not in any form of endoplasmic reticulum.

toLevel4.question: A cell diagram shows an organelle with a double membrane and stacked internal discs. The cell also has a cell wall. What organelle is this?

options.text: Chloroplast
options.explanation: Stacked internal discs (grana) within a double membrane identify the organelle as a chloroplast, consistent with a plant cell that has a cell wall.

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria have cristae (inward folds) rather than stacked discs, so this description does not match.

options.text: Golgi apparatus
options.explanation: The Golgi apparatus has flattened sacs but is a single-membrane system and does not have a double outer membrane.

options.text: Central vacuole
options.explanation: The central vacuole is a large single-membrane structure and does not contain stacked discs.

toLevel4.question: In a diagram, an organelle appears as a large, round structure surrounded by a double membrane with visible pores. What is this organelle?

options.text: Nucleus
options.explanation: The nucleus is a large, round organelle surrounded by a double membrane (nuclear envelope) with pores for molecular transport.

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria are typically smaller and elongated, with cristae inside rather than visible pores.

options.text: Central vacuole
options.explanation: The central vacuole is surrounded by a single membrane (tonoplast) and does not have pores in its membrane.

options.text: Lysosome
options.explanation: Lysosomes are small, single-membrane vesicles and do not have a double membrane with pores.

toLevel4.question: A student identifies a folded membrane network with dots on its surface as smooth ER. What correction should be made?

options.text: The dots indicate ribosomes, so it is rough ER
options.explanation: The dots on the membrane surface represent ribosomes, which is the defining feature of rough ER, not smooth ER.

options.text: The folds indicate cristae, so it is a mitochondrion
options.explanation: A membrane network is characteristic of ER, not mitochondria; cristae are folds inside the mitochondrial inner membrane.

options.text: The dots are nuclear pores, so it is the nucleus
options.explanation: Nuclear pores are found on the nuclear envelope, not on a folded membrane network like the ER.

options.text: Smooth ER has larger dots than what is shown here
options.explanation: Smooth ER does not have any dots (ribosomes) on its surface; the size of the dots is not the issue.

toLevel4.question: Which pair of organelles could both be present in a leaf cell but not in a muscle cell?

options.text: Chloroplasts and a large central vacuole
options.explanation: Leaf cells (plant cells) contain chloroplasts for photosynthesis and a large central vacuole, neither of which is found in animal muscle cells.

options.text: Mitochondria and a cell nucleus
options.explanation: Both mitochondria and a nucleus are found in muscle cells as well as leaf cells.

options.text: Rough ER and smooth ER together
options.explanation: Both types of ER can be found in muscle cells and leaf cells.

options.text: Ribosomes and a plasma membrane
options.explanation: Ribosomes and a plasma membrane are present in virtually all eukaryotic cells, including muscle cells.

toLevel4.question: A cell diagram shows an organelle with a double membrane, cristae, and its own small circular DNA. Which organelle does this describe?

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria have a double membrane, inner cristae folds, and contain their own small circular DNA, consistent with the endosymbiotic theory.

options.text: Nucleus
options.explanation: The nucleus has a double membrane and contains DNA, but the DNA is linear and the nucleus does not have cristae.

options.text: Golgi apparatus
options.explanation: The Golgi apparatus is a single-membrane system of flattened sacs and does not contain its own DNA.

options.text: Ribosome
options.explanation: Ribosomes are not membrane-bound organelles and do not contain DNA.

toLevel4.question: A cell with many {{blank:1}} but no chloroplasts is most likely an {{blank:2}} cell.
Rough ER is distinguished from smooth ER by the presence of {{blank:1}} on its {{blank:2}}.
A double membrane with internal {{blank:1}} identifies a chloroplast, while internal {{blank:2}} identifies a mitochondrion.

toLevel5.question: A diagram shows a cell with both chloroplasts and mitochondria. A student claims the cell does not need mitochondria because it can produce energy through photosynthesis. Evaluate this claim.

options.text: The claim is incorrect because photosynthesis produces glucose, which mitochondria must then break down to release usable ATP energy
options.explanation: Photosynthesis converts light energy into glucose, but cells still require mitochondria to break down glucose through cellular respiration to produce ATP for cellular processes.

options.text: The claim is correct because chloroplasts can produce all the ATP a plant cell needs during daylight hours without mitochondria
options.explanation: While chloroplasts generate some ATP during the light reactions, plant cells still depend on mitochondria for the majority of their ATP, especially at night.

options.text: The claim is incorrect because mitochondria are needed to produce chlorophyll for the chloroplasts to function properly
options.explanation: Chlorophyll synthesis does not depend on mitochondria; it occurs within the chloroplasts and cytoplasm via specific enzymatic pathways.

options.text: The claim is correct because chloroplasts and mitochondria perform the same function using different membranes inside the cell
options.explanation: Chloroplasts and mitochondria perform different functions: photosynthesis and cellular respiration respectively. They are not interchangeable.

toLevel5.question: Two diagrams show cells from the same plant: one from a leaf and one from a root. Which difference in organelle composition would you expect?

options.text: Leaf cells have chloroplasts while root cells lack them
options.explanation: Leaf cells contain chloroplasts for photosynthesis because they are exposed to light, while root cells are underground and typically lack chloroplasts.

options.text: Root cells lack mitochondria while leaf cells contain them
options.explanation: Both root and leaf cells contain mitochondria because all living plant cells require ATP from cellular respiration.

options.text: Leaf cells have a nucleus while root cells do not
options.explanation: Both leaf and root cells are eukaryotic and contain a nucleus with genetic material.

options.text: Root cells have rough ER while leaf cells only have smooth ER
options.explanation: Both root and leaf cells can contain rough and smooth ER; the type of ER present is not determined by location in the plant.

toLevel5.question: A student examines a cell diagram and identifies an organelle with a double membrane but no internal structures visible. Which explanation is most reasonable?

options.text: The diagram may lack detail, but the organelle is likely a nucleus, mitochondrion or chloroplast
options.explanation: Double-membrane organelles are limited to the nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts. The absence of visible internal structures may reflect the resolution or detail level of the diagram.

options.text: The organelle must be a lysosome because lysosomes have variable internal appearance depending on their contents
options.explanation: Lysosomes are single-membrane vesicles, so a double membrane rules out a lysosome regardless of internal appearance.

options.text: The organelle is smooth ER because smooth ER can sometimes appear to have two membrane layers when folded
options.explanation: Smooth ER is a single-membrane system; folding does not create a true double membrane as seen in the nucleus, mitochondria, or chloroplasts.

options.text: The organelle cannot be identified at all without visible internal structures present
options.explanation: The double membrane alone narrows identification to three possibilities, which is useful even without visible internal detail.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why recognising organelles by their structural features is more reliable than identifying them by size alone.

options.text: Organelle sizes vary between cell types but structural features remain consistent
options.explanation: Structural features like cristae, grana, nuclear pores, and ribosome-studded membranes are conserved, whereas organelle sizes can differ depending on cell type and function.

options.text: All organelles are exactly the same size in every type of eukaryotic cell
options.explanation: Organelle sizes differ significantly between cell types, which is precisely why size alone is unreliable for identification.

options.text: Structural features can only be seen with an electron microscope while size is always visible
options.explanation: Some structural features like the nucleus and chloroplasts can be seen with a light microscope, and size is not always clearly distinguishable.

options.text: Size is the primary method used by biologists to identify organelles in research
options.explanation: Biologists rely on structural features, staining patterns, and molecular markers rather than size alone for reliable organelle identification.

toLevel5.question: A cell has abundant rough ER and many Golgi bodies. What can you infer about this cell's primary function?

options.text: It likely specialises in producing and secreting proteins
options.explanation: Rough ER synthesises proteins via its ribosomes, and the Golgi apparatus processes and packages these proteins for secretion. Abundance of both suggests a secretory function.

options.text: It likely specialises in storing large volumes of water
options.explanation: Water storage is primarily associated with a large central vacuole, not with rough ER and Golgi bodies.

options.text: It likely specialises in photosynthesis and energy conversion
options.explanation: Photosynthesis requires chloroplasts; rough ER and Golgi abundance is not associated with photosynthetic function.

options.text: It likely specialises in breaking down cellular waste products
options.explanation: Waste breakdown is primarily associated with lysosomes; rough ER and Golgi abundance indicates protein production and secretion.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate why chloroplasts and mitochondria both having their own DNA supports the endosymbiotic theory and helps in their identification.

options.text: Their own circular DNA suggests they were once independent organisms, and this unique feature aids identification alongside their double membranes
options.explanation: The presence of circular DNA in both organelles supports the idea that they originated as free-living prokaryotes engulfed by ancestral eukaryotic cells. Their double membranes and own DNA are distinctive identification features.

options.text: Their DNA is identical to nuclear DNA, confirming they evolved within the cell and share the same membrane structure as the nucleus
options.explanation: Mitochondrial and chloroplast DNA is circular and distinct from the linear nuclear DNA, which supports an independent evolutionary origin.

options.text: Only mitochondria have their own DNA, so this feature cannot be used to identify chloroplasts in diagrams at all
options.explanation: Both mitochondria and chloroplasts contain their own circular DNA, supporting endosymbiotic theory for both organelles.

options.text: Their DNA prevents them from being visible under a microscope, making structural identification the only possible method
options.explanation: DNA does not affect visibility under a microscope; both organelles can be observed using appropriate microscopy techniques.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that all organelles with internal membrane folds must be mitochondria. Evaluate this reasoning.

options.text: This is flawed because chloroplasts also have internal membranes in the form of thylakoid stacks
options.explanation: Chloroplasts contain internal thylakoid membranes arranged in stacks (grana). The student should distinguish between cristae folds in mitochondria and thylakoid stacks in chloroplasts.

options.text: This is correct because only mitochondria contain any form of internal membrane structure within eukaryotic cells
options.explanation: This is incorrect; chloroplasts, the ER, and the Golgi apparatus all contain internal membrane structures.

options.text: This is flawed because the nucleus also has internal folds identical to mitochondrial cristae throughout its interior
options.explanation: The nucleus does not contain cristae-like folds; its interior contains chromatin and a nucleolus, not folded membranes.

options.text: This is correct because internal folds always indicate the presence of cristae used for cellular respiration
options.explanation: Internal membranes serve different functions in different organelles; thylakoids in chloroplasts are used for photosynthesis, not respiration.

toLevel5.question: Compare the consequences of misidentifying a chloroplast as a mitochondrion when interpreting a cell diagram in an exam.

options.text: It would lead to incorrectly attributing photosynthesis functions to an organelle that performs respiration
options.explanation: Confusing chloroplasts with mitochondria would result in assigning the wrong metabolic function, since chloroplasts perform photosynthesis and mitochondria perform cellular respiration.

options.text: It would make no difference because both organelles carry out the same biochemical reactions inside the cell
options.explanation: Chloroplasts and mitochondria perform fundamentally different metabolic processes: photosynthesis and cellular respiration respectively.

options.text: It would only matter if the cell also contained a nucleus, otherwise the functions are interchangeable
options.explanation: The functions of chloroplasts and mitochondria are never interchangeable, regardless of whether a nucleus is present.

options.text: It would have no impact because organelle identification is not assessed in VCE Biology examinations
options.explanation: Organelle identification from diagrams is a commonly assessed skill in VCE Biology examinations.
